title: Density Additivity Characterization
description: Characterize A, B ⊆ ℕ with positive density satisfying d(A+B) = d(A) + d(B). Known examples use fractional part sets {n : {nθ} ∈ X} for irrational θ. Are all such pairs generated by group rotation constructions?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Graham (1980, p. 51) asked for a characterization of pairs with additive density. The Plünnecke–Ruzsa inequality gives d(A+B) ≥ min(d(A)+d(B), 1), so exact equality is a strong constraint. The known examples come from Weyl equidistribution on the torus.
overview.problemStatement: Characterize all A, B ⊆ ℕ with positive density such that d(A+B) = d(A) + d(B).
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize asymptotic density, sumsets, density additivity, the fractional part construction, and the main conjecture that all examples come from group rotations.
keyInsights: d(A+B) = d(A) + d(B) implies d(A) + d(B) ≤ 1 — Plünnecke–Ruzsa is tight
Known examples: FractionalPartSet θ X for irrational θ, via Weyl equidistribution
The question generalizes to compact abelian groups beyond ℝ/ℤ
Density additivity is much stronger than the general sumset lower bound
This is a characterization problem, not a yes/no question

sections.title: Density Definitions
sections.summary: Defines counting function, asymptotic density, density existence, and positive density.

sections.title: Sumset and Additivity
sections.summary: Defines the sumset A+B and the density additivity condition d(A+B) = d(A) + d(B).

sections.title: Fractional Part Construction
sections.summary: Fractional part sets, Weyl equidistribution, and the known density-additive construction.

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: All density-additive pairs arise from group rotation constructions.

sections.title: Basic Properties
sections.summary: Density bounds, sum constraint, Plünnecke–Ruzsa, and tightness theorem.

conclusion.summary: Formalizes Erdős Problem #335 on characterizing density-additive pairs. The known examples come from fractional part constructions; the question is whether all examples have this group-theoretic origin.
conclusion.implications: A full characterization would connect additive combinatorics, ergodic theory, and harmonic analysis, explaining when sumset density is exactly additive.
openQuestions: Do all density-additive pairs arise from group rotations?
Are there 'exotic' examples not arising from compact abelian groups?
What is the structure of the set of valid density pairs (d(A), d(B))?
